doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF - GYNECOLOGY SERVICES 6 MONTH EXTENSION FUNDING MOD

FROM FLICKER TO JITTER: PREDICTING STELLAR RADIAL VELOCITY VARIATIONS FROM PHOTOMETRIC VARIABILITY. GIVEN THAT MOST EXTRASOLAR PLANETS ARE DETECTED BY THEIR INFLUENCE ON THEIR HOST STAR, THE HUNT FOR THESE OBJECTS IS LIMITED BY PROCESSES OCCURRING ON THE SURFACES OF THESE STARS STELLAR "NOISE" WHICH CAN SWAMP OR MIMIC PLANETARY SIGNALS. THIS IS PARTICULARLY SO IN THE RADIAL VELOCITY (RV) DOMAIN, WHERE THIS "NOISE" IS TERMED "JITTER." ADDED TO THIS, PHOTOMETRIC EXTRASOLAR PLANET SURVEYS, SUCH AS K2 AND TESS, WILL UNCOVER THOUSANDS OF TRANSITING PLANETS IN ADDITION TO THOSE FOUND BY KEPLER WHICH ARE ALREADY SEVERELY TAXING GROUNDBASED FOLLOW-UP RV RESOURCES: ONLY ~5% OF ALL PLANETARY CANDIDATES DISCOVERED BY KEPLER HAVE THUS FAR HAVE BEEN CONFIRMED BY RVS. IT IS THEREFORE IMPERATIVE TO DEVISE A SIMPLE WAY TO PRIORITIZE FUTURE FOLLOW-UP CAMPAIGNS, BY ENABLING PLANET HUNTERS TO PREDICT IN ADVANCE WHICH STARS WILL EXHIBIT THE LEAST RV NOISE. THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO USE ULTRA-HIGH PRECISION, LONG TIME-BASELINE LIGHT CURVES FROM NASA'S RE-PURPOSED KEPLER MISSION (K2) TOGETHER WITH RV JITTER MEASUREMENTS OBTAINED BY THE CALIFORNIA PLANET SEARCH (CPS) TO (1) DEVELOP AN EMPIRICAL PREDICTOR OF RV JITTER FROM LIGHT CURVES AND (2) EXAMINE THE AGE, ACTIVITY, AND SPECTRAL TYPE DEPENDENCE OF THESE RV JITTER-PHOTOMETRIC VARIABILITY RELATIONS. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK MAY ULTIMATELY ALLOW US TO FINALLY UNEARTH THE UNDERLYING PHYSICAL CAUSES OF POORLY-UNDERSTOOD RV JITTER. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A WAY TO USE THE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE LIGHT CURVES OBTAINED BY K2 TO ASSESS WHICH OBJECTS ARE MOST SUITABLE FOR RV PLANET SEARCHES. THIS WILL ENABLE RV TEAMS TO RESERVE THEIR TELESCOPE TIME AND RESOURCES ONLY FOR THE MOST INTERESTING AND PROMISING TARGETS RATHER THAN DEPLOYING THEM ON STARS THAT LATER TURN OUT TO BE TOO "JITTERY" FOR DOPPLER SEARCHES. AS SUCH, THIS PROPOSAL DIRECTLY SUPPORTS NASA'S GOAL OF UNDERSTANDING EXOPLANETARY SYSTEMS BY "[AIDING] IN THE DETECTION OF NEW EXOPLANETS." THE PROPOSED WORK WILL HAVE THE ADDED BENEFIT OF ENHANCING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE PHYSICAL ORIGINS OF JITTER, THEREBY ENABLING US TO DEVISE WAYS TO BYPASS OR REMOVE THE JITTER SIGNAL. THE RESULT: THE REMOVAL OF A FUNDAMENTAL LIMITING FACTOR IN RV PLANET SEARCHES, AND THE OPENING OF NEW RV PLANET SEARCH DOMAINS, SO KEY TO THE FULFILLMENT OF THE NASA SMD OBJECTIVE OF "[DISCOVERING] HOW THE UNIVERSE WORKS, [EXPLORING] HOW IT BEGAN AND EVOLVED, AND [SEARCHING] FOR LIFE ON PLANETS AROUND OTHER STARS." IN PARTICULAR, DETERMINING THE AGE-DEPENDENCE OF RV JITTER-PHOTOMETRIC VARIABILITY RELATIONS HAS THE POTENTIAL TO PERMIT THE RV DETECTION OF PLANETS AROUND YOUNGER, MORE ACTIVE STARS AND HENCE AID IN IMPROVING THE "UNDERSTANDING OF THE ORIGINS OF EXOPLANETARY SYSTEMS," ONE OF THE CORE GOALS OF THE XRP SOLICITATION.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF THE THERMAL TRANSPORT REQUIREMENTS FOR FUTURE SPACECRAFT MISSIONS CONTINUE TO INCREASE, APPROACHING SEVERAL KILOWATTS. AT THE SAME TIME THE HEAT ACQUISITION AREAS HAVE TRENDED DOWNWARD, THEREBY INCREASING THE INCIDENT HEAT FLUX. CURRENT INCIDENT HEAT FLUX FOR LASER DIODE APPLICATIONS IS ON THE ORDER OF 5-10W/CM2, ALTHOUGH THIS IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE TOWARDS 50W/CM2. THIS IS A SEVERE LIMITATION FOR AXIAL GROOVE ALUMINUM/AMMONIA CONSTANT CONDUCTANCE HEAT PIPES (CCHPS). THE MAXIMUM HEAT FLUX IN A CCHP IS SET BY THE BOILING LIMIT, WHICH TYPICALLY START AT 5 W/CM2 FOR AXIAL GROVE WICKS, AND 20-30 W/CM2 FOR POWDER METAL WICKS. THE INNOVATION IS TO DEVELOP CCHPS WITH A HYBRID WICK, WHICH HAS A SINTERED EVAPORATOR WICK, AND A CONVENTIONAL GROOVED ADIABATIC AND CONDENSER WICK. THESE HYBRID WICKS CAN OPERATE AT HIGHER HEAT FLUXES, ALLOWING THE USE OF HIGHER POWER LASER DIODES. THEY ALSO ALLOW THE USE OF VARIABLE CONDUCTANCE HEAT PIPES (VCHPS) IN LUNAR AND MARTIAN LANDERS AND ROVERS, WHICH MUST OPERATE AT TILTS UP TO 45. CONVENTIONAL ALUMINUM/AMMONIA HEAT PIPES CAN ONLY OPERATE WITH A 0.1 INCH TILT, SO THEY ARE UNSUITABLE. LOOP HEAT PIPES CAN ALSO OPERATE WITH TILTING, BUT THEY ARE TWO ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE MORE EXPENSIVE. A HYBRID GROOVED AND SINTERED WICK CCHP WILL ALLOW OPERATING AT HIGHER HEAT FLUXES AS COMPARED TO AXIAL GROOVE DESIGN AND CAN ALSO OPERATE AGAINST GRAVITY ON THE PLANETARY SURFACE, OPERATE IN SPACE, CARRYING POWER OVER LONG DISTANCES, ACT AS A THERMOSYPHON ON THE PLANETARY SURFACE FOR LUNAR AND MARTIAN LANDERS AND ROVERS, AND DEMONSTRATE A HIGHER TRANSPORT CAPABILITY THAN AN ALL-SINTERED WICK.

doc.ContractDescription: IGF::OT::IGF THIS FIRM-FIXED-PRICE (FFP) CONTRACT PROVIDES TECHNICAL SUPPORT SERVICES TO ASSIST THE U.S. COAST GUARD (USCG), OFFICE OF STANDARDS EVALUATION AND DEVELOPMENT (CG-REG), IN ITS COMPLIANCE WITH EXECUTIVE ORDER (EO) 12886, REGULATORY PLANNING AND REVIEW, AND THE GREAT LAKES PILOTAGE ACT OF 1960.

THE PROPOSED GRADUATE RESEARCH ATTEMPTS TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE QUESTIONS OF THE NASA SCIENCE MISSION DIRECTORATE SMD. ONE OF THE OVERALL GOALS OF THE NASA SMD IS TO ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE OF EARTH AS A SYSTEM TO IMPROVE LIFE ON OUR PLANET. THIS WORK WOULD COMBINE DATA FROM MULTIPLE SATELLITE SENSORS AS WELL AS IMAGE BASED DATASETS OF SHORT AND LONG TERM MEASUREMENTS TO STUDY ACTIVE VOLCANIC PROCESSES TO UNDERSTAND THESE PHENOMENA AND PROTECT LIVES AND PROPERTY. THE PRIMARY OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS THE NASA EARTH SCIENCE FOCUS AREA GOAL CHARACTERIZE THE DYNAMICS OF EARTH S SURFACE AND INTERIOR, IMPROVING THE CAPABILITY TO ASSESS AND RESPOND TO NATURAL HAZARDS AND EXTREME EVENTS. THE FUNDAMENTAL HYPOTHESIS OF THIS PROPOSAL IS, CAN PROXIMAL AND OPTICALLY THICK VOLCANIC PLUMES BE TREATED AS AN EMITTING SURFACE AND THEREFORE TO WHAT ACCURACY CAN TIR DATA BE USED TO DERIVE COMPOSITION, PARTICLE SIZE, AND LONGWAVE LW RADIATIVE FORCING? VOLCANIC PLUMES ARE A COMPLEX MIXTURE OF GAS AND SOLID PARTICLES OF MINERAL FRAGMENTS AND VOLCANIC GLASSES OF VARYING SIZES. BY EXAMINING THESE PRODUCTS, WE CAN GAIN A MUCH GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF THE DYNAMICS OF ERUPTION PLUMES AND THE UNDERLYING PROCESSES THAT GENERATE THEM. THIS ANALYSIS WILL THEREFORE ADDRESS ONE OF THE MAIN QUESTIONS OF THE EARTH SURFACE AND INTERIOR ESI SCIENCE FOCUS AREA, HOW DO MAGMATIC SYSTEMS EVOLVE AND UNDER WHAT CONDITIONS DO VOLCANOES ERUPT? FURTHERMORE, ONCE PLUMES HAVE BEEN GENERATED, THEY CAN MOVE GREAT DISTANCES AND HAVE SOME EFFECT ON BOTH REGIONAL AND GLOBAL CLIMATE. THE SHORT TERM AND LOCAL EFFECTS ON LW RADIATIVE FORCING OF THESE SPECIES ARE NOT FULLY UNDERSTOOD, PARTICULARLY IN THE CASE OF VOLCANIC ASH. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL THEREFORE PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION FOCUS AREA MISSION STATEMENT TO ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF CHANGES IN THE EARTH S RADIATION BALANCE, AIR QUALITY THAT RESULT FROM CHANGES IN ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION, BY EXAMINING THE COMPLEX ROLES OF TRANSMISSION, ABSORPTION, AND EMISSION BY THESE CLOUDS. THIS IN TURN PROVIDES A CROSSOVER TO THE CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND CHANGE GOAL, TO IMPROVE THE ABILITY TO PREDICT CLIMATE CHANGES BY BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE ROLES AND INTERACTIONS OF THE ATMOSPHERE, LAND IN THE CLIMATE SYSTEM. THE WORK WILL USE SPECTRAL DATA DERIVED FROM A NEWLYDEVELOPED ASH FLOW CHAMBER IN THE LABORATORY AS WELL AS FROM THE ADVANCED SPACEBORNE THERMAL EMISSION AND REFLECTION RADIOMETER ASTER SENSOR AND ITS URGENT REQUEST PROTOCOL URP ARCHIVE, WHICH HAS BEEN DEVELOPED FOR DETECTING AND MITIGATING VOLCANIC HAZARDS. IN ADDITION TO ASTER, THIS WORK IS ADAPTABLE TO ALLOW OTHER EOS INSTRUMENTS ON THE TERRA, AQUA AND AURA E.G. MODIS, AIRS, ETC SATELLITES TO BE USED TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTAND OF THE ERUPTIVE COMPOSITION, VOLCANIC CHANGES TO THE ATMOSPHERE, AND HAZARDS POSED BY VOLCANIC ASH CLOUDS.

doc.ContractingAgency: 7523: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

doc.ContractDescription: USING BOTH ASTER THERMAL INFRARED (TIR) AND VISIBLE-NEAR INFRARED (VNIR), WITH ERS-2 AND ALOS PALSAR MICROWAVE SAR SENSORS (C- AND L-BANDS) THERE IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO FORECAST FUTURE EXPLOSIVE VOLCANIC ACTIVITY IN HIGHLY POPULATED, DEVELOPING COUNTRIES. THE RESEARCH PROPOSED HERE WILL FIRST REFINE MODELS OF SURFACE COMPOSITION AND ROUGHNESS USING PUMICE AND OBSIDIAN SAMPLES FROM MONO DOMES (CALIFORNIA, USA) BEFORE APPLICATION TO EXISTING PYROCLASTIC FLOW AND LAHAR DEPOSITS AT MERAPI VOLCANO (INDONESIA) AND SHIVELUCH VOLCANO (RUSSIA). SHIVELUCH AND MERAPI VOLCANOES HAVE HAD NUMEROUS ERUPTIONS IN THE PAST DECADE THAT HAVE PRODUCED MANY DIVERSE SIZES AND STYLES OF FLOW DEPOSITS. IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT SURFACE TEXTURE AND COMPOSITION OF LAHAR AND PDC DEPOSITS CAN BE CHARACTERIZED USING TIR AND SAR DATA TO UNDERSTAND THE ERUPTIONS THAT FORMED THEM. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH QUANTIFYING AND INTEGRATING: 1) DEPOSIT MORPHOLOGY; 2) MICRON- (VESICULARITY) SCALE AND CM- (BLOCK SIZE) ROUGHNESS; AND 3) COMPOSITION. THESE PARAMETERS INDICATE MAGMA COMPOSITION, VOLATILE CONTENT AND FRAGMENTATION CONDITIONS AND THE INTEGRATION OF THESE DATASETS AIMS TO IDENTIFY DEPOSIT TYPE AND ORIGINATING ERUPTIVE STYLE, AND RESULTING HAZARDS TO LOCAL POPULATION AND PROPERTY. THIS DATABASE CAN GIVE INSIGHT TO THE MAGMA SYSTEM EVOLUTION AND FUTURE ERUPTION STYLE TO AID IN DISASTER MANAGEMENT AND DECISION MAKING. COMPOSITIONAL DATA WILL BE DERIVED USING SATELLITE THERMAL INFRARED SPECTRAL DECONVOLUTION METHODS DESCRIBED BY RAMSEY AND CHRISTENSEN (1998). MICRON-SCALE SURFACE ROUGHNESS WILL BE QUANTIFIED BY IMPROVING THE VESICULARITY MODEL DEVELOPED BY RAMSEY AND FINK (1999) USING A TWO-COMPONENT SPECTRAL DECONVOLUTION MODEL APPLIED TO TIR WAVELENGTHS AND COMPARED TO SEMDERIVED ROUGHNESS VALUES. THESE RESULTS WILL BE EXTENDED TO SURFACE MORPHOLOGY DERIVED FROM OPTICAL WAVELENGTHS, AND BLOCK SIZE MEASUREMENTS DERIVED FROM SAR DATA OF THE SAME FLOWS AND SUBSEQUENTLY CORRELATED TO PREVIOUS GROUND- AND LAB- BASED STUDIES OF THESE DEPOSITS. THE DATA PRODUCED BY THIS RESEARCH WILL BE CORRELATED TO PAST VOLCANIC ACTIVITY, AND THEN COMBINED WITH TOPOGRAPHICAL DATA FOR VOLCANIC HAZARD APPLICATION TO ASSESS RISK TO LOCAL POPULATIONS. THIS RESEARCH AIMS TO IMPROVE REMOTE SENSING MODELING OF EXPLOSIVE ERUPTIONS THROUGH STUDIES IN AREAS DIFFICULT TO ACCESS AND MONITOR, INCLUDING HUMID, CLOUD-COVERED ENVIRONMENTS THAT ARE A CHALLENGE TO REMOTE SENSING, WHICH ARE AREAS THAT COMMONLY HAVE INCREASED POPULATIONS IN HARM'S WAY.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE K2 MONITORING OF KNOWN, NEARBY TRANSITING PLANET PHASE CURVES, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF RADIAL VELOCITY PLANET HOSTS AS WELL AS LONG-TERM PRECISE RV TARGETS IN THE CAMPAIGNS 6&7 FIELDS. NEARBY KNOWN PLANETS ARE ALL ORBITING BRIGHT STARS (V<13) AND HAVE RV MEASUREMENTS. CONTINUOUS K2 MONITORING OF THESE RARE BUT IMPORTANT TARGETS WILL PROVIDE INVALUABLE DATA FOR DETAILED HIGH PRECISION CHARACTERIZATION OF BOTH THE PLANETS AND THEIR HOST STARS. PREVIOUS K2 CAMPAIGNS, UNFORTUNATELY, HAVE MISSED A FEW OF THESE BRIGHT AND KNOWN PLANETARY SYSTEMS (E.G., WASP-17, HD 99492). WE THEREFORE PROPOSE AND URGE CAMPAIGNS 6&7 TO INCLUDE THESE SYSTEMS. IN PARTICULAR, CAMPAIGNS 6&7 WILL HAVE BETTER POINTING THAN PREVIOUS ONES, AND CAMPAIGN 6 WILL COVER A HIGH GALACTIC LATITUDE, PROVIDING THE HIGHEST AVAILABLE PHOTOMETRY QUALITY IN K2. OUR MAIN SCIENCE GOALS ARE: (1) MEASURE THE OPTICAL PHASE CURVES AND SECONDARY ECLIPSES OF TWO KNOWN TRANSITING HOT JUPITERS, QATAR-2B AND WASP-55B, TO DETERMINE THEIR OPTICAL ALBEDOS, HEAT REDISTRIBUTION, AND ECCENTRICITIES. IN PARTICULAR, QATAR-2B IS ONE OF THE BEST TARGETS FOR ATMOSPHERIC CHARACTERIZATION IN BOTH OPTICAL AND NEAR-IR, AND PROVIDES A RARE OPPORTUNITY FOR JOINT STUDIES OVER A WIDE WAVELENGTH RANGE. (2) IMPROVE THE ORBITAL AND PHYSICAL PARAMETERS OF BOTH TRANSITING SYSTEMS AND BETTER CONSTRAIN THE MASSES, RADII AND DENSITIES OF THE PLANETS. (3) CHARACTERIZE THE STELLAR PROPERTIES (ROTATION, ACTIVITY, JITTER, FLICKER) OF KNOWN RV PLANET HOSTS AND LONG-TERM RV TARGETS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE STARS, THEIR PLANETS, AND AID THE SEARCH OF LONG-PERIOD PLANETS IN THESE SYSTEMS. (4) SEARCH FOR PLANET TRANSITS IN THE RV SYSTEMS. WE PROPOSE A TOTAL OF 28 TARGETS, INCLUDING 2 TRANSITING PLANETS AND 26 KNOWN RV PLANETARY SYSTEMS AND LONG-TERM PRECISE RV TARGETS IN CAMPAIGNS 6&7. WE REQUIRE SHORT CADENCE DATA FOR THE KNOWN TRANSITING PLANETS IN ORDER TO CONSTRAIN THE INGRESS AND EGRESS TIMING OF THEIR TRANSITS AND ECLIPSES TO PRECISELY MEASURE THEIR ECCENTRICITY AND ORBITAL PARAMETERS. WE ONLY NEED LONG CADENCE DATA FOR THE REST OF THE RV SYSTEMS. WE WILL IMPLEMENT THE DETRENDING AND CALIBRATION METHODOLOGY DEVELOPED BY VANDERBURG&JOHNSON (2014) AND COMBINE IT WITH OUR OWN ALGORITHMS TO EXTRACT THE RAW K2 LIGHT CURVES. OUR TRANSITING PLANET HOST STARS ARE IN THE MAGNITUDE RANGE OF 11 TO 13 MAG IN THE VISIBLE, FALLING IN THE SWEET SPOT OF THE DEMONSTRATED K2 PRECISION OF 30 - 40 PPM PER 6- HOUR INTEGRATION (VANDERBURG&JOHNSON 2014), SUFFICIENT TO MEASURE THE OPTICAL PHASE CURVES AND SECONDARY ECLIPSES OF THESE BEST HOT JUPITERS WITH HIGH SIGNIFICANCE WHEN COMBINING THE 80-DAY DATA TOGETHER. OUR SCIENCE GOALS ARE DIRECTLY RELATED TO EXOPLANET DETECTION, CHARACTERIZATION AND STELLAR ASTROPHYSICS, ALL OF WHICH ARE THE MAIN AREAS OF THE K2 GO PROGRAM AND NASA S EXOPLANET EXPLORATION PROGRAM. THESE OBSERVATIONS CANNOT BE REPLICATED FROM THE GROUND DUE TO THE REQUIREMENT OF CONTINUOUS MONITORING AND VERY HIGH PRECISION FOR OPTICAL PHASE CURVES. PARTICULARLY, THE OPTICAL PHASE CURVES WILL BE RARE AND VALUABLE DATASETS FOR EXOPLANET CHARACTERIZATION BEFORE THE ERA OF TESS.

doc.ContractDescription: THE NEXT MAJOR X-RAY ASTRONOMY OBSERVATORY WILL BE ESAS L2 MISSION, WHICH IS LIKELY TO BE THE ADVANCED TELESCOPE FOR HIGH-ENERGY ASTROPHYSICS (ATHENA). ONE OF THE CORE ATHENA INSTRUMENTS, THE WIDE FIELD IMAGER (WFI), IS DESIGNED TO CONDUCT SENSITIVE OBSERVATIONS OF BOTH BRIGHT AND FAINT X-RAY SOURCES USING A WIDE FIELD OF VIEW AND A NEW TYPE OF DEVICE KNOWN AS A DEPFET (DEPLETED P-CHANNEL FIELD EFFECT TRANSISTOR) DETECTOR, WHICH HAS AN EXTREMELY RAPID READOUT CAPABILITY. A KEY TECHNOLOGY REQUIRED TO READ OUT AND PROCESS THE DATA FROM AN ARRAY OF DEPFET DETECTORS IS A VERY HIGH SPEED HARDWARE/FIRMWARE EVENT RECOGNITION PROCESSOR. WE HAVE DEVELOPED A DESIGN CONCEPT AND ARE SEEKING FUNDS TO ADVANCE THE DESIGN TO TRL 4.
